long:
- DSDM is a rapid application development method in the UK
- Focuses on fixing time and resources, adjusting functionality accordingly
- Core principles include focusing on business needs, delivering on time, collaborating, maintaining quality, building incrementally, developing iteratively, communicating continuously, and demonstrating control
- Disadvantages include limiting creativity and requiring a reliable structure for successful implementation
- The DSDM lifecycle involves five major phases: feasibility, business study, functional model iteration, design and build. - Implementation phase:
  - Review project specifications for feasibility
  - Ensure goals can be met within budget, timeline, and technology
- Business study phase:
  - Research project from a business perspective
  - Evaluate alignment with organization goals, competition, and user needs
- Functional model iteration phase:
  - Build and test prototype based on specifications
- Design and build phase:
  - Refine prototype for efficiency and address issues
  - Test product for responsiveness and ease of use
- Implementation phase:
  - Release project for operational use and gather user feedback
  - Determine if adjustments are needed based on user feedback
- Lifecycle roles:
  - Business Sponsor, Business Visionary, Project Manager, Technical Coordinator, Business Analyst, Technical Advisor, Business Advisor, Team Leader, Solution Developer, Solution Tester, Workshop Facilitator, DSDM Coach
- LEAN (Kanban):
  - Lean development practices based on successful manufacturing methods
- Kanban principles:
  - Start with what is needed now, incremental change, respect current process, encourage leadership at all levels. - Visualize the Workflow:
  - Helps understand planned changes and implement them accordingly
  - Card wall with columns representing workflow steps is common visualization method
  
- Limit Work in Progress:
  - Implements a pull system in workflow
  - Using kanban system helps implement pull system
  - Work-in-process is limited at each state in the workflow

- Manage Flow:
  - Monitor, measure, and report transitions between workflow states
  - Evaluates changes to system effects

- Make Process Policies Explicit:
  - Discuss and improve processes effectively
  - Move discussions from emotional to rational, empirical

- Feedback Loops:
  - Encourages small incremental changes
  - Teams measure effectiveness through tracking various metrics

- Improve Collaboratively:
  - Achieve sustainable change through shared vision and understanding

Positive Side of Kanban:
- Everyone on the same page
- Reveals bottlenecks in workflow
- Brings flexibility
- Team more responsive
- Easy access for remote team members
- Flow analytics

Negative Side of Kanban:
- Outdated board can lead to issues
- Overcomplicating the board
- Lack of timing associated with phases
